data: Five joining fragments of the upper part of a thick limestone slab, intact on the top, left and right, broken across the lower part, with damage to the lower right margin higher than on the left, beginning from line 6 of the text. The rear of the stone is finished also. Fragment A (upper left): max W 20.5 cm, max H. 19, D 6.9-8.1; fragment B (upper right): max W 17 cm, max H 18.5, D 7.3-8.5; fragment C (lower left): max W 14.5, max H 11.5, D 6.8-7.0; fragment D (lower middle): max W 3.5cm, max H 3, D (damaged) 3.5; fragment E (lower right) missing.
The left margin of the text is carefully justified, but the right margin is very uneven, with several extensive vacats at line end.

Regular small letters of generally consistent size, deeply cut with pronounced terminal serifs on some strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, occasional extension of apex; beta appears open with rounded but not fully circular equal loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar, and upper and lower strokes often curve outwards at the ends; theta is ovoid with complete horizontal bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; mu has middle stroks joining well above the line; nu has the lower right angle above the line with shorter right vertical stroke; omicron is smaller and above the line; pi has shorter right vertical; rho is closed with generally circular eye; sigma has upper and lower horizontals curving slightly outwards at the ends, and the middle strokes often form into a single curving stroke; phi has a rounded eye, with the vertical extended, up to 17mm; psi has extended vertical and straight arms; omega is small, rounded, above the line, and open, with generally horizontal tail strokes.
Found by a local farmer in the area of Colle Orbo c.1968
Photo J. Prag, Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

Further comments on 'epica religiosa' (ZPE 50, 1983, 1-6), a Sibylline oracle
H.W. Parke, ‘Further Comments on “epica Religiosa” (ZPE 50, 1983, 1-6), a Sibylline Oracle’, Zeitschrift Für Papyrologie Und Epigraphik 63 (1986): 47–51

Iscrizioni, epigrafi ed epigrammi in Greco della Sicilia orientale di epoca romana

(SEG XXXI, 1981, 821 e 822)», in Dinamiche culturali ed etniche nella Sicilia orientale dall’età classica all’epoca ellenistica, a c. di T. Alfieri Tonini e S. Struffolino (Trento: Tangram Edizioni Scientifiche, 2014), 127–36

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Manganaro 1992, but checked against the stone by autopsy (Prag);
  • line.19: The top of either a Φ or a Ψ is visible in approximately the fifth position of the line

translation

commentary

Of the five fragments, three are large (a, b, c) and two very small (d and e); the smallest (e), from the bottom edge of the join between the two principal fragments, is currently unlocated and not with the other fragments. The text should be considered alongside ISic003367; it was recovered together with that piece (although there is no evidence of how close the asssociation was). The letter forms are effectively identical on the two pieces, probably cut by the same hand.

Italy Sicily Siracusa Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi 66527 Ancient Greek

Five joining fragments of the upper part of a thick limestone slab, intact on the top, left and right, broken across the lower part, with damage to the lower right margin higher than on the left, beginning from line 6 of the text. The rear of the stone is finished also. Fragment A (upper left): max W 20.5 cm, max H. 19, D 6.9-8.1; fragment B (upper right): max W 17 cm, max H 18.5, D 7.3-8.5; fragment C (lower left): max W 14.5, max H 11.5, D 6.8-7.0; fragment D (lower middle): max W 3.5cm, max H 3, D (damaged) 3.5; fragment E (lower right) missing.

limestone plaque 27.5 35 8.5

The left margin of the text is carefully justified, but the right margin is very uneven, with several extensive vacats at line end.

chiselled

Regular small letters of generally consistent size, deeply cut with pronounced terminal serifs on some strokes. Alpha is broad with straight bar, occasional extension of apex; beta appears open with rounded but not fully circular equal loops; epsilon has shorter middle bar, and upper and lower strokes often curve outwards at the ends; theta is ovoid with complete horizontal bar; kappa has short, equal length tails; mu has middle stroks joining well above the line; nu has the lower right angle above the line with shorter right vertical stroke; omicron is smaller and above the line; pi has shorter right vertical; rho is closed with generally circular eye; sigma has upper and lower horizontals curving slightly outwards at the ends, and the middle strokes often form into a single curving stroke; phi has a rounded eye, with the vertical extended, up to 17mm; psi has extended vertical and straight arms; omega is small, rounded, above the line, and open, with generally horizontal tail strokes.

Line 1-19 5-7 Interlineation line 1 to 2 not measured Acrae near Palazzolo Acreide 37.05780, 14.89346 2nd century BCE Found by a local farmer in the area of Colle Orbo c.196837.054649, 14.899828 Depositi, Mag C, cass.113/04 2011-06-16; 2013-10-02 (Prag)

Τετραλεα δ’ αὐτὸμ προσέφημ· Πάτερ, ἤλυθα τιμὴν εἴ τινά μοι δοίης· τὰ δ’ ἐφήμερά μ’ οὐδ’ ἰσάασιν ὤλλοις δ’ εἰσὶ τεχνῶν εὑρείματα, καρποὶ ἅπασιν, μνημείων ὅσιοι τιμαὶ καὶ ἅγεια σέβουσιν. Μαίη δ’οὐδ’ ἐφορᾶι με μόνημ, πάντως δ’ ἀγέραστος. τόσσ’ ἐφάμην· ὁ δὲ νεῦσε κάρα καὶ θεῖά μοι εὔδα· οὐδεὶς ἀθανάτωμ φθαρέει βροτόν, οὐδ’ ἀνελήσει ἢ σύ, τέκος, καὶ Φοῖβος ἑκαβόλος ἰῶι, οὐδ’ αὐτῶι θεμιτόν τιν’ ὀλεῖν, οἷ χρησμῶι ἕπονταν. ἄλλος ἄφωνα κατ’ ἄστρα φυέντων τῷ μόρος· εἴ τις σοί τι πρόσεισι κράτει, τιμῆι δέ τοι οὔτις ὅμοιος ἥρως, προσθεμένῃ Νύμφας ἐπὶ πᾶσιν ὄρεσσιν. Μαίη, δ’ οὐ χρησμούς σοι ἔφαινεν εἰ δ’ αὖ καί τι θέλεις, χρηίζε ἐνθεάσασ’ ἀβροτῇ νυκτὶ ἔκτοσε θυη εμε ὃν δὴ ἐποψ ταῦτα γ
Text after Manganaro 1992, but checked against the stone by autopsy (Prag) The top of either a Φ or a Ψ is visible in approximately the fifth position of the line

Of the five fragments, three are large (a, b, c) and two very small (d and e); the smallest (e), from the bottom edge of the join between the two principal fragments, is currently unlocated and not with the other fragments. The text should be considered alongside ISic003367; it was recovered together with that piece (although there is no evidence of how close the asssociation was). The letter forms are effectively identical on the two pieces, probably cut by the same hand.
